revision.text: {{Rueda Command TR| title=Dame Tres| pronunciation=dAH-may trezz| english=Give me three| summary=The same as [[Rueda de Casino/Dame|dame]], but miss out two partners| related=[[Rueda de Casino/Dame Dos|Dame Dos]] }} This is like [[Rueda de Casino/Dame Dos|dame dos]], but instead of missing out one partner, the leader misses out two. The same technique is used for this as for [[Rueda de Casino/Dame Dos|dame dos]]. Note: This move can be dangerous, be careful. [[Category:Rueda de Casino]]

revision.comment: [[Talk:Light – Wave or stream of particles?]] moved to [[Talk:Optics/Light]]
revision.text: This page has been proposed for speedy deletion with only the comment "nonsense" as justification. Once this book gets developed this will be a resonable page to have. The page topic is completely valid.

{{WikiProject Languages}}
==An exhortation, if you will.==
If you google up "latin subjunctives," the first entry points to Wikibooks Latin, and the second to this page. Needless to say, this is shamefully inadequate coverage of the subjunctive. I made the edits from October 4th in the history, but it's clear that that's far from enough. It also should probably be better organized. Maybe split up subjunctive form and subjunctive uses?
Point is, if this is topping the Google ranks, then it had better live up to it. Or else people aren't going to be getting very lucky. [[User:4.156.117.143|4.156.117.143]] 04:49, 14 March 2006 (UTC)
Have ''any'' of you learned subjunctives ''before'' doing active and passive verbs? I certainly haven't. The chapter order here makes no sense.
Also, how did it go from the version of this page in May to what it was a few days ago? When/why did that happen?
And where do we go over the uses of the subjunctive? Hortatory, indirect commands, jussive, c-clauses, quominus clauses, etc? I thought I saw a page for that earlier, but now I can't find it. [[User:216.20.1.213|216.20.1.213]] 11:27, 4 October 2005 (UTC)
== Moods ==
I reverted the edit which said Latin has 5 moods. I may be wrong. As far as I know there are 3 moods (indicative, imperative and subjunctive) but some might claims that the ''infinitive, gerund, participle, gerundive and supine'' are moods also. If there's a Latin expert who knows better then please go ahead and correct it.--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|<sup>talk</sup>]] 23:09, 16 November 2011 (UTC)

revision.comment: Austncorp moved page [[Cookbook:Gumbo]] to [[Cookbook:Chicken and Andouille Sausage Gumbo]]: This is a recipe for a sub-category of gumbo rather than a recipe for the usually expected item.
revision.text:
{{recipesummary||3|1 hour|3|}}
{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:North American cuisines|North American Cuisines]]
'''Chicken and Andouille Sausage Gumbo''' is a soup or [[Cookbook:Stews | stew]] which is is prepared using [[Cookbook:Roux | roux]].
== Ingredients == * 1 cup (240 ml) canola oil * 1 cup (240 g) [[Cookbook:Flour | flour]] * [[Cookbook:The Trinity | Trinity]] (all chopped to 1/4" inch) :* 2 bell pepper :* 1 large onion :* 4 stalks of celery * Chicken stock or equivalent * Chicken breasts (about 2 lbs or 1 kg) * Andouille sausage or other spicy sausage (about 1/2 lb or 1/4 kg) * [[Cookbook:Cayenne Pepper | cayenne pepper]] to taste * [[Cookbook:Salt | salt]] to taste
== Procedure == # Brown outside of chicken breasts in small amount of oil then set aside. # Make a [[Cookbook:Roux|roux]] in a large saucepan. # Add Trinity to roux and soften. # Slowly stir in water. # Cut up chicken breasts and add to gumbo to cook until done. # Slice up sausage and add 1/2 hour later. # Simmer. Serve in a bowl with a little rice and green onions on top. Gumbo will be better if left over night and eaten the next day.
== Notes, tips, and variations == *Refer to reputable cooking website for genuine recipes. This one is very simplified and will really disappoint. *Hot sauce can be added to taste. *[[Cookbook:Filé|Filé]] may be added to thicken individual servings as served. *Use home-made chicken stock instead of water. Water has no flavor by itself, and store-bought chicken stock has way too much salt.
[[Category:Louisiana recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Chicken recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Sausage recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: update info; add subheading on Re-reading and Donella Meadows
revision.text:
Kathryn Hatcher served on the [http://www.uga.edu/ University of Georgia] faculty (1978-2006) at the [http://www.ecology.uga.edu/ Institute of Ecology] in Athens, Georgia USA, and previously worked for State of Maryland [http://www.dnr.state.md.us/ DNR] Water Resources Administration (1974-78). She graduated from Georgia Tech ([http://www.ce.gatech.edu/ BCE], 1972) and MIT ([http://web.mit.edu/civenv/parsonslab/ SMCE], 1974).
==== Useful links ==== *[http://www.bedfordstmartins.com/online/cite5.html#top Using MLA Style to Cite and Document (Internet) Sources] *[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries#Footnotes Example of using footnotes]
==== Worth Re-reading ====
* [http://sysdyn.clexchange.org/sdep/papers/D-4143.pdf Donella Meadows article], from Creative Learning Exchange.

revision.comment: [[Wikibooks talk:Wikijunior:New Title Suggestions]] moved to [[Wikijunior talk:New Title Suggestions]]: Wikijunior is a namespace now
revision.text: ==What to do now?== Where to we go from here? I would like to start a new "Wikijunior" book by November 1st, but I don't want to run roughshod over anybody else right now, nor show "favoritism" to any particular book suggestion. The point here is that we want to have an orderly process of new Wikibooks coming "on-line" so that we don't overwhelm ourselves with so much work that we can't get it all done, but at the same time try to expand the community so people with diverse interests may want to participate. Ultimately, I would like to do something like the current "Book of the Month" voting process, where we can vote on what the next title for Wikijunior should be. Any other thoughts? --[[User:Robert Horning|Rob Horning]] 14:51, 4 October 2005 (UTC) :Yes, voting is a good idea. We're all more likely to contribute to books we've voted for. After all, you wouldn't vote for it unless you thought it was interesting or doable. But based on the current amount of participants, I don't think having a ''monthly'' vote would be a good idea. Maybe more like three our four months would be a good time to vote. That seems to be how long it takes for a Wikijunior book to get off the ground. If more regular participants show up, then one to two months.--[[User:Shanel|Shanel]] 23:19, 5 October 2005 (UTC) ::How about quarterly votes for now? That way we can try to "publish" about 4 Wikijunior books per year. With the current level of participation with the Wikijunior books, I think that may be possible, particularly if we start to get some publicity from some of the existing Wikijunior books, and that means we have already some "in the pipeline" that are ready to go as well. If support is strong, we can scale back the time between votes, but it may mean that we have higher quality books anyway if we keep the number down. I just want to make '''''some''''' way for new titles to be suggested and to keep the process moving. Being totally stagnant with no new titles is going way too far. --[[User:Robert Horning|Rob Horning]] 22:00, 6 October 2005 (UTC) :::Quarterly votes sound good. I think one of the reasons we don't have alot of partcipants is because we've had the same three topics up for about a year. (Ancient Civilizations doesn't count :)) And really, most people are turned off by the fact that there's nothing much left to write. Fact-checking and copy editing, how exciting! But still, having new topics will hopfully encourage more long-term participation in Wikijunior.--[[User:Shanel|Shanel]] 04:27, 13 October 2005 (UTC) == [[Wikijunior:New Book of the Quarter]] == I just added this page to help decide what new project we should start. In some ways, I would like this to be a vote that ends on December 1st rather than January 1st, but simple calendar quarters that end in January, April, July, and October do make sense and are fairly standard. Feel free to change the rules or anything about this page as well. I'm just trying to '''__BE BOLD__''' and get something accomplished. --[[User:Robert Horning|Rob Horning]] 08:25, 4 November 2005 (UTC) == New Category Suggestion == I am putting this on the discussion page instead of the New Title page because it is for a new category to list on the main page, instead of a single new book. I suggest we add a '''Unit Study''' or '''Lesson Plan''' category. I have been spending quite a bit of time proofreading the Solar System book this week in some attempt to get the "almost done" books all the way to "finished". The teacher in me cannot help writing a lesson plan in my head that uses this book as the main source as I go along. I realize that lesson plans require a bit more knowledge on how to actually teach children than writing the text does, but it would be an excellent resource to add anyway. Both companion lesson plans to the existing Wikijunior canon and stand-alone unit studies could be listed in the category. [[User:Starchildmom|Starchildmom]] 22:30, 3 April 2006 (UTC) == Unfinished Book Proposals == I have created a section for suggested book titles that lack enough information to be included in the voting, that are unfinished, that do not have any registered users listed as interested participants. I would also like to include a section for withdrawn proposals (There is one.) I would also like to list all the non-cannonical books under Unfinished Book Proposals (if they are not already listed.) I have also created an "Adopted Wikijunior Titles" section. I think Breaking it up like this makes it a lot more manageable. --[[User:Xixtas|Xixtas]] 03:08, 26 September 2006 (UTC) == Naming Consistency and Sort Order == I think that all the suggested book titles should leave off the "Wikijunior" at the front. So instead of [[Wikijunior Bugs]] I would favor [[Wikijunior Bugs|Bugs]]. Also, I think each section should be in alphabetical order. == Archival and Rework == I have changed this page up quite a bit. If anyone hates it, feel free to revert. I have archived off the old book suggestions and changed the template for new suggestions. My intent is to create new book suggestions based on the books that got more than two votes last quarter and the books that have already been started, but never received book of the quarter. The reason that I have done this is because I would like us to generally have a higher quality of book suggestions and a lower quantity. --[[User:Xixtas|xixtas]] [[User_Talk:Xixtas|talk]] 02:32, 3 April 2007 (UTC)

=Introduction= [[Image:Tiger_Desktop.png|none|thumb|830px|Fig. 1 - The Tiger Desktop.]] If you think the Mac desktop looks good enough to eat, you're not alone. The Mac desktop is arguably the prettiest in the business, with translucent accents and candy-colored graphics. But what do the things on desktop actually do? This chapter explains the two main elements, the Dock and the Menu Bar, in full detail.
=The Dock= [[Image:Tiger_Dock.png|center|thumb|830px|Fig. 2 - The Dock. Since the Dock is highly customizable, the one shown here may not look exactly like yours.]]
The ribbon of icons at the bottom of the screen is called the “Dock”. It combines many of the elements found in other operating systems into one compact little bar. Let's take a look at what the Dock can do and how it can do it.
If you look carefully at the Dock, you’ll see it’s cut in two by a thin, dark line. Each side of the Dock does very different things.
==The Left Side== We’ll start by looking at the left side. All of the icons in the left side of the Dock are for various applications (programs). You can do two things with these icons:
* Launch Applications - If you click on an unopened application’s icon, that application will launch (open) right then and there. The icon will bounce as the application launches.
* Switch Between Open Applications - If an application is ''already'' open (indicated by a tiny black triangle under the icon or a blue dot), clicking its icon will "switch" to that application (bring its windows out in front of all others).
{{Mac Note Box|The Applications you see on your Dock actually live in a special folder on your hard drive (called the Applications folder), which you'll learn more about in [[Mac OS X Tiger/Using the Finder|Chapter 3]]. The applications appear on the Dock as well for your convenience.}}
Of course, ''you'' get to pick which applications appear on ''your'' Dock. Apple starts you out with a few it thinks you’ll like, but you're encouraged to pick your own. Let’s say you’re a frequent user of Adobe Photoshop. Rather then root through your Applications folder every time you need to open Photoshop, you can put its icon on your Dock, so you can open it with just one click.
How does one go about doing this? To add an application’s icon to the Dock, you simply drag it out of your Applications folder and drop it over the Dock where you want it to appear. The icons already in the Dock even scoot out of the way to make room! The application is still in the Applications folder as always, but now ''also'' appears in the Dock for quick access.
To remove an application that you don’t want on your Dock anymore, simply drag its icon outside of the Dock and drop it anywhere, and it will evaporate in a puff of cartoon smoke (remember that the real Application is unaffected). You can also reorganize icons already in the Dock by dragging them horizontally. This doesn't work if an application is running, which we'll get to later.
{{Mac Note Box|If the icons in the Dock refuse to budge, then the most likely explanation is that the “Administrator” (owner) of your computer has banned you from customizing your Dock.}}
It's also important to know that <font style="BACKGROUND-COLOR: FFFF66">whenever you open an application that’s not usually in the Dock, its icon appears in the Dock temporarily. When you quit the application, the icon automatically disappears</font>. This is the single most confusing thing about the Dock. Why does Mac OS X do this? Remember that the left side of the Dock not only lets you launch applications, but also switch between ones that are already opened. If you can't switch between ''every'' open application, regardless of whether they're used enough to warrant a permanent spot in the Dock or not, then the Dock fails as a good application switcher. While this is a bit difficult to understand, think about it carefully until you see how it makes sense.
==The Right Side== Having discussed the left side of the Dock, it's time to look at the right side. The right side has absolutely nothing to do with switching or launching applications; its duties are much less important. It has four tricks up its sleeve:
* The Trash - The right side of the Dock has a little trash can icon glued into it. Covered fully in [[Mac OS X Tiger/Using the Finder|Chapter 3]], this icon is used to delete files on your Mac.
* Files - Just like the left side of the Dock lets you keep your favorite programs handy, the right side is the perfect place to park your favorite files and folders. You can drag files in and out just like you would an application in the left side of the Dock. To open a file or folder in the Dock, simply click on it.
* Links - In addition to files, the right side of the Dock can keep links to your favorite websites handy. Adding a link is as simple as dragging it into the right side. To remove a link, which looks like a circular springboard bearing an "@" sign, simply drag it out.
* Windows - When you minimize a window, a little thumbnail appears in the right side of the Dock. Minimizing is explained in the [[Mac OS X Tiger/The Mac Interface|next chapter]].
{{Mac Trick Box|If you right-click an icon in either side of the Dock, it will sprout a menu with some nifty options. The options vary dramatically depending on what the icon is. For instance, the menu for the iTunes icon will let you control the music that’s currently playing. Or how about if you right-click a folder in the right side of the Dock? The menu contains commands for quick access to every single file in that folder. Experiment and see what other menus you can discover!}}
==Customizing the Dock== Now you understand the Dock’s many abilities. But as if choosing which icons go in your Dock isn’t enough, you can even modify the appearance of the Dock itself! If you want really fine-grained control over the Dock, you’ll need to delve into something called System Preferences, detailed later on in its own chapter. But many tweaks can be performed right from the Desktop.
A majority of the Dock controls on your Desktop reside in the " > Dock" menu up in the Menu Bar. These include:
* Turn Magnification On - When you select this, your Dock responds with a neat “bulge” effect as you move your cursor over it. You’ll either love it or hate it. If this option is already active, it's replaced with “Turn Magnification Off”, which, as you might guess, turns the effect off.
* Turn Hiding On - If you have a small monitor, you’ll love this feature. It makes the Dock disappear completely unless you let your cursor rest right next to the edge of your screen where your Dock is. The Dock will then temporarily pop out so you can work with it. If this option is already active, it's replaced with “Turn Hiding Off”. You can also toggle this option on and off using ⌘⌥D.
* Position on Left, Position On Bottom, Position on Right - These three options let you select where on the screen the Dock appears. A checkmark appears next to the currently selected one. Most people leave their Dock on the bottom, but some people prefer their Dock on the side.
* Dock Preferences - A handy shortcut to Dock Preferences (part of System Preferences).
But there's one option you can't adjust in the " > Dock" menu, and it's possibly the most important. If you would like to adjust the size of the Dock, click and drag the thin dividing line in the Dock up (to enlarge) or down (to shrink).
{{Mac Trick Box|If you hold down Shift while dragging the dividing line, you can change the position of the Dock on screen.}}
=The Menu Bar= <font style="BACKGROUND-COLOR: FFFF66">The thin, white, strip running across the top of the screen is called the "Menu Bar".</font> It's a very important part of Mac OS X indeed. It contains a large number of commands and options, organized into "menus". Read on to learn more.
==Using Menus== [[Image:Tiger_Finder_Menu.png|thumb|272px|right|Fig. 3 - A menu in the menu bar.]] <font style="BACKGROUND-COLOR: FFFF66">If you've used a computer before, you'll know that menus are lists of items (usually commands or options) which the user can choose from</font>, just like a menu at a restaurant is a list of meals which a customer can choose from. Menus are found in many different places in Mac OS X, but by far the most popular place is in the Menu Bar.
The Menu Bar is a unique Mac OS X feature. In other operating systems, ''every window'' has its own menu bar. This causes a lot of unsightly clutter and wasted space, since you can only use one window's menu bar at a time anyway. So Apple designers gave the Mac one big Menu Bar at the very top of the screen. Depending on what window you are working with, different menus appear in the Menu Bar, alongside certain menus that appear no matter what you are currently doing.
Each menu in the Menu Bar is identified by a word or symbol. These are called "titles". The title of the menu in Fig. 3 is "Finder". Click on a menu's title, and the menu appears directly underneath, somewhat like a pull-down window shade. The menu will stay open until you '''a)''' choose a command by clicking on it, or '''b)''' close the menu by clicking elsewhere. If one menu is already open, you can switch to another menu simply by rolling your mouse over any other menu's title.
If a command in a menu can be activated using a keyboard shortcut (or "keystroke"), then the keystroke appears to the right of the command itself. As you can see, the keystroke for activating the command "Hide Finder" in the menu shown in Fig. 3 is "⌘H".
{{Mac Note Box|For information on how to execute a keyboard shortcut, see the "Shortcut Shorthand" section on this wikibook's main page.}}
A few more menu tips, in no particular order: *Commands that open dialog boxes or sheets always end with an elipsis (...). *Some menus are hierarchal; that is, a menu can be nested ''inside'' another menu. These nested menus are called "sub-menus", and are marked by small arrows. *Some commands found in menus toggle on or off when you choose them. A checkmark next to the command's name indicates that it is "on". *If a command is not applicable at the moment, it appears dimmed. If all commands in a menu are not applicable, the menu's title appears dimmed, but you can still open the menu to take a peek at what it contains. *Sometimes (but rarely), a few commands in a menu change slightly when you hold down a modifier key. For instance, the "Minimize" command in most applications' "Window" menu turns into a "Minimize All" command when you hold down the Option key. *If a menu is too large to see all at one time, arrows appear at the top and bottom. Roll over an arrow, and the menu will "scroll" through the availible options.
==The Menu Bar from Left to Right== Now that you know how to operate menus in the Menu Bar, we'll go across the Menu Bar from left to right and look at each menu you'll see.
===The  Menu=== [[Image:Tiger_Finder_Menu_Bar.png|center|thumb|675px|Fig 4. The left side of the menu bar.]] At the far left side of the menu bar is the  menu, which is represented by a blue Apple logo. It contains twelve items relevant to the entire Mac environment, and is always visible. The commands within let you turn off or restart your computer, log out, tweak some settings, update your software, etc. Here's a complete list:
* About This Mac - This opens a dialog box with a few bits of information about your Mac. The dialog box also has a button that opens System Profiler, a utility that can tell you the exact specifications of your Mac. * Software Update - A link to Software Update, a dialog box which, oddly enough, is for updating your Mac’s software. * Mac OS X Software - Takes you to a special page on Apple’s website expressly for downloading Mac software, most of which is free. * System Preferences - Opens System Preferences, (See [[Mac OS X Tiger/System Preferences|Chapter 7]]). * Dock - A menu within a menu. This was discussed when we talked about the Dock, earlier in this Chapter. * Location - This is used in networking. (See [[Mac OS X Tiger/Networking your Mac|Chapter 9]]). * Recent Items - A list of recently used files and applications. * Force Quit - If an application is misbehaving and refuses to quit, you can "Force Quit" it to pull the plug on it and let it die. Choosing this command opens a small force quit dialog box, which presents a list of running applications. Choose the one you want to force quit and press the pulsating blue "Force Quit" button to finalize your decision. When you're finished, close the dialog box and get on with your life. This is a safe procedure, and it won't affect Mac OS X as a whole or any other applications you have running. {{Mac Trick Box|If you hold down Shift, this becomes Force Quit [Current App], which Force Quits the app that you are using.}} * Sleep, Restart, Shut Down - These are pretty self-explanatory. They make your Mac sleep, restart, or shut down. * Log Out [Your Name Here] - If you have multiple accounts on your Mac (See [[Mac OS X Tiger/User Accounts|Chapter 8]]), you can log out and let someone else onto your Mac with this command.
===The Application Menu=== To the right of the  menu is the Application menu. <font style="BACKGROUND-COLOR: FFFF66">This menu's title is the same as the name of the application you are currently using</font>. For example, if you're using iTunes, the menu is called “iTunes". The menu contains commands relevant to the application itself: you can find information about it, quit it, hide it, and adjust its preferences.
===Other Menus=== Next to the Application menu are a few other menus containing commands for application you're currently using. <font style="BACKGROUND-COLOR: FFFF66">While every app uses a different set of menus, there are some menus used often throghout most programs</font>. This section lists the six most commonly used menus (from left to right in the most common order) and the kind of commands you're most likely to find in them. ====File Menu==== The File menu contains commands pertaining to an individual file that you're working on. You'll find commands related to creating new files and opening, closing, saving, and printing ones that are currently open.
====Edit Menu==== The Edit menu contains commands pertaining to an application's data, and the clipboard. You can use the edit menu to:
*Undo and Redo actions you perform *Select All of a window or text field's contents *Insert special characters such as é,æ,€, and ⌘ *Manipulate the contents of the clipboard, which helps you move content between windows and applications. **Cut - Removes the selected data and puts it in the clipboard, overwriting whatever was on the clipboard before. **Copy - Makes a duplicate of the selected data and stores it in the clipboard, overwriting whatever was on the clipboard before. **Paste - Inserts the contents of the clipboard into where you are currently working. The contents of the clipboard remain, so you can paste the same thing multiple times. **Paste and Match Style - Found in some text-editing applications, the Paste and Match style command pastes the text and adjusts its style to match the style of the surrounding text. **Delete - Deletes whatever is selected (the contents of the Clipboard are unaffected).
====Format Menu==== Text-editing apps often include this menu for adjusting the formatting (appearance) of text. However, this menu is often changed beyond recognition in non-Apple applications, which insist on using their own set of commands in totally different places. The Apple-sanctioned commands for this menu are:
*Format selected text with different fonts, sizes, colors, and effects *Copy the style of one block of text and "paste" (apply) the exact same styling to another block *Adjust alignment and the window's ruler (if the window indeed has one) *Copy the ruler (alignment settings) of one block of text and paste it to another
====View Menu==== The View menu contains commands that let you choose what you see on your screen and how you see it.
====<Other Menus Go Here>==== Applications that use menus not described in this chapter always stick them here, between the View menu and the Window menu.
====Window Menu==== This menu contains commands for managing all of an application's open windows (windows are explained in more detail in the next chapter). You can:
*Minimize and Zoom windows *Bring all of an application's windows to the front of the stack, with or without arranging them for easy access
The window menu also contains a complete list of windows for the current application. Choosing a window brings it out in front of all others. The frontmost window is marked with a check, minimized windows are marked with a diamond, and windows containing unsaved changes are marked with a circular dot.
====Help Menu==== The Help Menu contains commands for opening the help system for the current Application.
===The Gap=== This white space separates everything explained above from everything explained below.
===The Menu Bar Extras=== The menus on the right side of the menu bar look a little bit different, since they consist not only of words but of symbols. These are called “Menu Bar Extras”. Menu Bar Extras are always in your menu bar, and let you do things like change your computer's sound volume, see the time, view your laptop’s battery life, etc. Coverage for them is scattered throughout this Wikibook.
{{Mac Note Box|If there isn't enough room on your screen to show the complete contents of the menu bar, the menu bar extras are temporarily hidden to make room.}}
[[Image:Tiger_Righthand_Menu_Bar.png|center|thumb|675px|Fig 5. The right-hand side of the menu bar. You can customize it with different menulets, so yours may not look exactly like this one.]]
===The Spotlight Menu=== Finally, at the far right of the menu bar, is the Spotlight menu, which looks like a little white magnifying glass in a blue circle. It lets you use Spotlight search technology, a new feature in Tiger, and is covered in the [[Mac OS X Tiger/The Mac Interface|next chapter]]. [[Mac OS X Tiger/The Mac Interface|Next Chapter ->]] ===Navigation=== Previous Page : [[../Introduction|'''Introduction''']] Next Page : [[../A Quick Look Under the Hood|'''A Quick Look Under the Hood''']]
[[Category:Mac OS X Tiger]]

revision.comment: Added all remaining shortcut keys to safari
revision.text:
NOTE: The "Command" key is also known as the Apple key.
===At Startup=== *Force Mac OS X Startup - "X" during startup (when MacOS 9 is also installed) *Bypass primary startup - "Delete-Option-Command-Shift" during startup *Startup from Optical Drive (CD/DVD) - "C" during startup *Netboot - "N" during startup *Safe boot mode - "Shift" during startup *Single User mode - "Command-S" during startup *Verbose mode - "Command-V" during startup *Open Firmware - "Command-Option-O-F" during startup *Startup Manager - "Option" during startup *Reset Parameter Ram - "Command-Option-P-R" during startup *Eject CD - Hold down mouse button at startup *Target Disk mode - "T" during startup
===At Login=== *Disable login items - "Shift"
===Screenshots=== * Take Picture of Entire Screen - '"Command-Shift-3" * Take Picture of Selection - "Command-Shift-4" provides a selection tool. Click and drag to select any area of the screen. *Take Picture of Object/Window - "Command-Shift-4, Space" changes your cursor into a camera. Click a window or menu to take a picture of it.
Holding ''Control'' while using any of the above three commands places the screenshot on the clipboard instead of as a file on the desktop.
===Most Applications=== *Hide Current Application - "Command-H" *Hide All Other Applications - "Command-Shift-H" *Toggle Dock Hiding - "Command-Option-D" *Minimize Current Window to Dock - "Command-M" *Minimize All Windows in Current Application to Dock - "Command-Option-M" *Bring Next Window in Current Application to Front - "Command-`" *Bring Previous Window in Current Application to Front - "Command-Shift-`" *Preferences - "Command-, (comma) " *Create new Document - "Command-N" *Save Current Document - "Command-S" *Save Current Document As - "Command-Shift-S" *Close Current Window - "Command-W" *Print Current Document - "Command-P" *Page Setup - "Command-Shift-P" *Undo - "Command-Z" *Cut - "Command-X" *Copy - "Command-C" *Paste - "Command-V" *Help - "Command-?"
===Most Dialogs=== *Cancel - "Escape", "Command-." *Default Button - "Enter" *Selected Button (highlight around button) - "Space"
===Finder=== *New Folder - "Command-shift-N" *Duplicate (File/Folder) - "Command-D" *Make alias - "Command-L" *Show Original of alias File/Folder - "Command-R" *New Window -" Command-N" *Get Info (File/Folder) - "Command-I" *Home Folder - "Command-shift-H" *Applications Folder - "Command-shift-A" *Utilities Folder - "Command-shift-U" *Icon view - "Command-1" *List view - "Command-2" *Column view - "Command-3" *Open Spotlight - "Command-Space" * "Command-Del" - moves selected item(s) to Trash * "Command-Up Arrow" - opens parent directory * "Command-Down Arrow" - open Highlighted icon - [same as double clicking on selected icon] * "Command-space" - show Spotlight search field * "Command-A" - Select All * "Command-C" - Copy selected * "Command-D" - Duplicate seleced item(s) * "Command-F" - open Find * "Command-H" - hide Finder * "Command-I" - Get Info on selected * "Command-J" - toggle Show View Options window * "Command-K" - open Connect to Server dialog * "Command-M" - minimize active Window - [same shortcut works in most apps] * "Command-N" - open New Window - [same shortcut works in most apps] * "Command-O" in Finder - open Selection - [same as double clicking on selected item(s)] * "Command-O' in Other Apps - open File * "Command-R" - selects Original when an Alias is selected * "Command-V" - Paste - [depending on what you have copied depends on how it works] * "Command-W" - close active Window - [same shortcut works in most apps] * "Command-X" - Cut * "Command-Z" - toggles between Undo/Redo last change * "Command-L" - make Alias to selected item(s) * "Command-Option-space" - show Spotlight window * "Command-space" - show Spotlight menu * "Command-Shift-upArrow" - when a finder Window is active, makes the Desktop active * "Command-Shift-delete" - empty Trash, with Confirmation Dialog * "Command-Shift-A" - go to Applications folder * "Command-Shift-C" - go to Computer Folder * "Command-Shift-D" - open Desktop Folder - [does not work for me under 10.4.3 - it is documented in Apple's Help] * "Command-Shift-G" - open Go To Folder dialogue box - allows you to type in a path * "Command-Shift-H" - go to Home Folder * "Command-Shift-I" - open iDisk or opens dialog - part of Apple's dotMac/.mac service * "Command-Shift-J" - launch JavaBrowser * "Command-Shift-K" - open Network Browser - [seems buggy under 10.4.3 - a window must be open, nothing shows up] * "Command-Shift-N" - create New Folder <!-- Not Finder specific --> * "Command-Shift-Q" - log out * "Command-Shift-U" - open Utilities Folder * "Command-Shift-O" - open * "Command-Shift-T" - Add to Favorites * "Command-Shift-Option-delete" - delete Trash, without Confirmation Dialog
===Safari===
*Previous page - "Command-[" *Next page - "Command-]" *Zoom in - "Command-+ (plus)" *Zoom out - "Command-- (hyphen)" *Hide toolbar - "Command-|" *Hide bookmarks bar - "Command-Shift-B" *Show Tab bar - "Command-Shift-T" *Show Status bar - "Command-/" *Stop (loading page) - "Command-." *Add bookmark - "Command-D" *Add bookmark to menu - "Command-Shift-D" *Mail contents of this page - "Command-I" *Mail link to this page - "Command-Shift-I" *Block Pop-ups - "Command-K" *Goto address bar - "Command-L" *Reload Current Page - "Command-R" *New Tab - "Command-T" *Close Tab/Window - "Command-W" *Goto first 9 bookmarks on bookmarks bar - "Command-1-9" *Next Tab - "Command-shift-[ (left sq. bracket) " *Previous Tab - "Command-shift-] (right sq. bracket)" *Autofill form - "Command-Shift-A" *Home - "Command-shift-H" *Actual size - "Command-Option-0" *Show top sites - "Command-Option-1" *Show all history - "Command-Option-2" *Show all activity - "Command-Option-A" *Show all bookmarks - "Command-Option-B" *Empty cache - "Command-Option-E" *Block pop-up windows - "Command-Option-K" *Downloads - "Command-Option-L" *Search results snapback - "Command-Option-S" *Show source - "Command-Option-U"
Develop menu keys (activated from advanced options) *Show Error Console - "Command-Option-C" *Show web inspector - "Command-Option-I" *Start profiling javascript "Command-Shift-Option-P"
===Mail=== *New Message - "Command - N" *Reply - "Command - R" *Forward - "Command - Shift - F" *Send - "Command - Shift - D" *Search mail - "Command - Option - F" *Go to Inbox - "Command - 1" *Go to Drafts - "Command - 3" *Go to Sent - "Command - 4" *Go to Trash - "Command - 5" *Scroll messages - "up/down arrows" (toggle between message and mailbox scroll with "tab") *Scroll within mail - "page up/down" *Go to top of message list - "Command-Shift-Home" *go to bottom of message list - "Command-Shift-End"
===Dashboard=== *Display removal handle for a widget - "Option" and mouse over the top-left-hand corner *Refresh/reload widget - "Command - R" *Reveal/hide the widget bar - "Command -= (equal sign) "
===Services=== Note: These shortcuts can be overridden by the current application, or other services using the same shortcut.
* "Command-Shift-8" - Get Result of AppleScript * "Command-Shift-B" - Send File to Bluetooth Device… * "Command-Shift-F" - Spotlight * "Command-Shift-J" - View in JavaBrowser * "Command-Shift-L" - Search with Google * "Command-Shift-Y" - Make New Sticky Note

revision.comment: /* ''' Example of Time Domain Solution''' */ Removed image with unknown copyright
revision.text:
{{Engineering Acoustics}}
== '''d'Alembert Solutions''' ==
In 1747, [http://www-groups.dcs.st-and.ac.uk/~history/Mathematicians/D'Alembert.html Jean Le Rond d'Alembert]published a solution to the one-dimensional wave equation.
The general solution, now known as the d'Alembert method, can be found by introducing two new variables:
<math>\xi=ct-x\,</math> and <math>\eta=ct+x\,</math>
and then applying the chain rule to the general form of the wave equation.
From this, the solution can be written in the form:
<math>y(\xi,\eta)= f(\xi)+g(\eta)\,=f(x+ct)+g(x-ct)</math>
where f and g are arbitrary functions, that represent two waves traveling in opposing directions.
A more detailed look into the proof of the d'Alembert solution can be found [http://mathworld.wolfram.com/dAlembertsSolution.html here. ]
== ''' Example of Time Domain Solution''' ==
If f(ct-x) is plotted vs. x for two instants in time, the two waves are the same shape but the second displaced by a distance of c(t2-t1) to the right.
The two arbitrary functions could be determined from initial conditions or boundary values.
[http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Engineering_Acoustics Back to Main page]

{{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Bread|Bread]] {{recipe summary | category = Bread recipes | servings = | time = 1 ¼ - 3 hours | difficulty = 2 | image = | energy = | note = }} This recipe makes a little more dough than enough for a 1-pound loaf of bread. It is intended to be kneaded in a bread machine, and baked in an oven. ==Ingredients== :{| style="text-align:center;" |- ! width-"700px"|Volumetric
Original recipe text and ingredient order preserved. Weight conversions from USDA National Nutrient Database. Milliliter values were ignored. Honey was presumed in the range of 1 teaspoon to 1 tablespoon. || Grams
  || [[wikipedia:baker percentage|Baker's %]]
  |- | align=left | 1 cup (heated for about 40 seconds in the microwave) [[cookbook:water|water]] ||width="145"|237 ||width="145"|86.5% |- | align=left | 2 teaspoons (10 mL) [[cookbook:sugar|sugar]] || 8.4 || 3.07% |- | align=left | 1 teaspoon (5 mL) [[cookbook:salt|salt]] || 6 || 2.19% |- | align=left | 2 cups [[Cookbook:Flour|high-gluten (strong) flour]] (bread flour in the U.S.) || 274 || 100% |- | align=left | 1-4 teaspoon (5-20 mL) [[Cookbook:Yeast|active dry yeast]] The minimum amount of yeast will result in a slightly strong yeast flavor, and increase with higher values. To reduce this flavor, it is recommend to use no more than 0.75% instant dry yeast expressed as a baker's %, alternatively, 2.5% cake yeast (compressed) or 1% active dry yeast, although you can expect fermentation time to increase somewhat. || 4-16 || 1.46-5.84% |- | align=left | 1 spoon full of honey || 7-21 || 2.55-7.66% |- ! align=right | Formula || 536.4-562.4 || 195.77-205.26% |} == Procedure == # Add ingredients to a 2-pound capacity [[Cookbook:Bread Machine|bread machine]] in the order listed, select dough cycle, and press start. # Remove when cycle is complete. # Preheat oven to 400 [[Cookbook:F|°F]] (200 [[Cookbook:C|°C]]) # When dough is finished, form into desired shape on a floured surface, and place on baking sheet or pizza stone. There is no [[wikipedia:Proofing_(baking_technique)|proofing]] time specified. # [[cookbook:Bake|Bake]] until lightly brown and firm. Cooking time will vary with altitude (20-40 minutes). # Cool and enjoy. ==Variations== *To make a twist loaf, roll dough into a cylindrical shape with your hands, but make one end of the cylinder thicker than the other. Then divide the cylinder with a knife down the center of the thicker end, creating a ring with a protruding cylinder. Braid and bake. *Brush loaf with an eggwash (1 egg + a scant amount of water) or egg white, melted margarine or butter, or olive oil for a crisper crust. *Sprinkle brushed loaf with minced garlic, chopped herbs, ground spices, grated cheese, ground pepper and/or kosher salt for flavor. *Toss or roll into a flat disc and top with tomato sauce, olive oil, chopped meat, vegetables and/or grated cheeses to create a pizza (bake until cheese is melted). ==Conversion Notes== {{Reflist|group=note}} [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Baking recipes]] [[Category:Recipes_with_metric_units|{{PAGENAME}}]]

revision.comment: /* Are some of them famous even today? */
revision.text:
== What country did they live in? == The Akkadians lived on the Arabian Peninsula, a piece of land that sits between Europe, Africa, and Asia. Today, many countries share this land, including Yemen, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Israel, Jordan, Iraq and Kuwait.
The Akkadians lived on the Arabic peninsula then migrated north which created a big conflict with the Sumerian city-states. The Akkadians finally settled in Mesopotamia. Today this area is part of the Middle East.
== What did their buildings look like? == They built many types of buildings, including large temples and monuments. Their most famous buildings are called ziggurats, which are sort of like square pyramids. The first floor is the largest, and each floor up gets progressively smaller until you reach the top room. The Tower of Babylon is one famous example of this kind of building. The Akkadians buildings were made with handfuls of wet clay. The walls were poorly constructed. One way walls were made was to outline the shape of your house with lumps of clay and let it dry in the hot sun. A faster way was to use wood planks and put a layer of clay between each board. Their houses were shaped like domes, the whole dome was made out of clay.
== What did they eat? == Akkadians hunted fish, duck, and geese. They also ate dates, bread, onions, beans, cucumbers, garlic, and a few other fruits and vegetables. Then they would wash it down with beer or water.
== What did their writing look like? ==
The language used a writing system called cuneiform. Wedge shaped symbols or strokes were carved or pressed into clay tablets with a reed stylus. This writing system was invented by the Sumerians around 3500 BC. Akkadians put their language into cuneiform and many early stories were found preserved in Akkadian text.
== What did they believe? == The Akkadians adopted the Sumerian culture and its ideas. The Sumerians were polytheistic. The Sumerian's Gods An, En-lil, and En-ki lost supremacy to Astral Triad, which consisted of Sin (the moon), Ishtar (venus), and Shamash(the sun).
== Are some of them famous even today? == None recorded because this was an ancient civilization
== What is left of them today? == The Akkadians were Semitic people and their descendants survive today among the modern Arabs and Jews .
== When did their civilization exist? ==
The Akkadian civilization existed during the Mesopotamian times. About 6,000 years ago they lived with the Sumarians and Babylonians. The Babylonians, Sumerians, and the Akkadians all lived in peace with each other. They did not war with the other civilizations, they actually traded. They overran Sumer between 2400BC and 2100BC. Eventually they were conquered by the Babylonians. They still lived in Mesopotamia but eventually died out with the Sumarians.
== External Links ==
*[http://www.wildfowlmagazine.com-sub.info Wild Fowl Magazine] *[http://www.historyguide.org/ancient/lecture4b.html History Guide] *[http://www.vnc.qld.edu.au/enviro/suner/2002-c.htm] *[http://www.brlsi.org/proceed05/antiquity1104.html] *[http://www.ancient.org/cerealfoodsworld/samplepdfs/CFW-51-0004.pdf] *[http://www.wsu.edu/~dee/MESO/AKKAD.HTM]
== References ==
*Mesopotamia: the Mighty Kings. Alexandria, Virginia: Time-Life Books, 1995. *Oxford First Ancient History by: Roy Burrell *Jacob, Heidi Hayes, Michal L. LaVasscur and Bredna Randolph. World Explorer The Ancient World. Needham, Massachuserrs: Prentice Hall, 1998 *Chisholm, Jane. The Usborne Book Of The Ancient World. London: Usborne Publishing Ltd, 1991.
{{BookCat}}
[[de:Wikijunior Alte Zivilisationen/ Akkader]]
{{Wikijunior article stub}}

= My Store =
You can set up many fundamental features in ''My Store''.
== '''My Super Store''' ==
This is the name of the website as presented to the public. The shopper's web browser window displays on the title bar.[[:Image:]]
== Store Owner ==
The name of the store owner. On the web page as the customer sees it this appears at xxx.
== Store Logo ==
This is the logo that appears in the top left hand corner of all pages and on the customer receipts.
== E-Mail Address ==
The main store's email address. On the web page as the customer sees it this appears at xxx.
== E-Mail From ==
When you send an email to your customers this is the email address they will see that it is from. This is also the return email address will be this.
== Country ==
This is the country in which the store is based. On the web page as the customer sees it this appears at xxx.
== Zone ==
This is the zone in which the store is located within that country. xxx.
== Expected Sort Order ==
CRE Loaded can sorts lists of products and other types of lists. You can choose whether they ascend (i.e. a, b, c, d or 1, 2, 3, 4) or descend (i.e. d, c, b, a or 4, 3, 2, 1) here.
Set this value to ''asc'' for an ascending order or ''desc'' for a descending order.
== Expected Sort Field ==
CRE Loaded will sort this field.
You have two choices: ''date_expected'' and ''products_name''. They are self explanatory.
== Switch To Default Language Currency ==
If this is set to ... the default language currency is always used when a customer first arrives at your site.
== Send Extra Order Emails To ==
When your customer makes an order, this option will allow you to specify which emails extra orders should be sent to.
== Use Search-Engine Safe URLs (still in development)==
Sites such as Google dislike the long database derived URLs that CRE Loaded uses. This option will attempt to disguise the URLs, so Google and others are more likely to link to your pages.
You should note that this feature is still in development. Do not use it unless you realise what you are doing.
== Display Cart After Adding Product ==
Customers will see their shopping cart straight away after adding to it. The advantage is that customers are encouraged to purchase goods straight away and are less likely to wander-off. The disadvantage is that they are less likely to add more products to the cart. You may want to test market this feature in order to decide whether you want it on or off.
== Allow Guest To Tell A Friend ==
Do you want to allow people who are not logged-in to tell a friend about one of your products? Absolutely yes!
Do you want to allow spam-bots which are not logged-in to send spam from your servers? Definitely not!
Be careful if you turn this option on. Seek help to keep it from being exploited.
== Default Search Operator ==
When searching the store customers will often type more than one word into the search box. You can make the default search operator '''and''' or '''or''' as follows:
''first search term'' '''and''' ''second search term''
or
''first search term'' '''or''' ''second search term''
For instance if a customer searches for ''baking tray'' and the default search operator is set to '''and''' then all products which contain ''baking'' '''and''' ''tray'' will be included in the search. Similarly if this value is set to '''or''' then all products which contain ''baking'' '''or''' which contain ''tray'' will be included in the results list.
== Store Address and Phone ==
Put your address and phone number here.
== Show Category Counts ==
The server will count recursively how many products are in each category. This is displayed xxx.
== Allow Category Descriptions ==
Turn this on to enable full text descriptions for categories.
== Enable Admin Dhtml menu ==
Turn this on to enable drop-down menus in the admin section. They look pretty cool - but be careful as they don't always work on everybody's set up - the side menus will disappear and you won't be able to change it back if there is a problem.
== Tax Decimal Places ==
This is the number of decimal places that are included in sales tax.
== Show Featured Products on Main Page ==
If you want Featured products to be shown on the main page switch this value on.
== Display Prices with Tax ==
You can either display the product with the price including tax, or the price excluding tax.
== Welcome Gift Voucher Amount ==
When customers register for your store you can give them a fixed gift voucher.
== Welcome Discount Coupon Code ==
Newly registered customers can be given a discount coupon here.
== Category/Products Display Order ==
This is the order in which category/ products should be displayed.
[[Category:CRE Loaded Features]]

{{{1|Welcome, {{PAGENAME}}!}}} {| style="background:white; border:1px solid #abd5f5;; padding:0px; border-spacing:0px; color: #000000;" ! style="background:#d0e5f5; color: #000000;" | [[Wikibooks:Welcome|Getting started]] with Wikibooks |- | style="padding:5px;" | * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. Find out [[WB:WIW|what this means]]. * To sign your name (on talk pages), use four tildes, like this: ~~~~ * For help in using the wiki, see [[Using Wikibooks]]. * For information about the community here, see [[Wikibooks Community]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold|be bold]], and have fun! |} Come introduce yourself at the [[WB:SLN|new users]] page. If you have any questions, you can ask there or contact me personally. * Please also check out the [[Cookbook:Policy|Cookbook policy]] page and the [[Talk:Cookbook|Cookbook talk]] pages. [[User:Kellen|Kellen]] [[User_talk:Kellen|T]] 20:32, 4 October 2005 (UTC) == Your account will be renamed ==
Hello, The developer team at Wikimedia is making some changes to how accounts work, as part of our on-going efforts to provide new and better tools for our users like cross-wiki notifications. These changes will mean you have the same account name everywhere. This will let us give you new features that will help you edit and discuss better, and allow more flexible user permissions for tools. One of the side-effects of this is that user accounts will now have to be unique across all 900 Wikimedia wikis. See [[m:Special:MyLanguage/Single User Login finalisation announcement|the announcement]] for more information. Unfortunately, your account clashes with another account also called Mm35173. To make sure that both of you can use all Wikimedia projects in future, we have reserved the name Mm35173~enwikibooks that only you will have. If you like it, you don't have to do anything. If you do not like it, you can [[Special:GlobalRenameRequest|pick out a different name]]. Your account will still work as before, and you will be credited for all your edits made so far, but you will have to use the new account name when you log in. Sorry for the inconvenience. Yours,
[[m:User:Keegan (WMF)|Keegan Peterzell]]
Community Liaison, Wikimedia Foundation
23:31, 17 March 2015 (UTC) == Renamed ==

revision.comment: [[WB:REVERT|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/183.82.97.201|183.82.97.201]] ([[User talk:183.82.97.201|talk]]) to last version by Avicennasis
revision.text:
== First Name ==
This is the minimum number of characters you allow a first name to have. A reasonable number is 2, any more and people called Jo cannot use your store!
== Last Name ==
This is the minium number of characters that a last name (surname) can have - as with first name 2 is a resonable number.
== Date of Birth ==
This is the earliest date you allow people to use as their date of birth. Of course setting this date too late will mean you cannot benefit from the custom of "silver surfers".
== E-Mail Address ==
This is the shortest number of characters you would like to allow in an email address.
== Street Address ==
This is the shortest number of characters in the street address that you will allow a customer to have.
== Company ==
This is the least number of characters that you will allow a company to register.
== Post Code ==
This is the shorted number of characters to allow when a customer registers their post code.
== City ==
This is the shortest number of letters that you will allow a customer's city to be.
== State ==
This is the shortest number of letters that you will allow for a state.
== Telephone Number ==
This is the shortest number of digits you will allow in the registering customer's telephone number.
== Password ==
This is the shortest password that you will allow registered customers to have. Make this short enough for customers to remember and long enough so that you do not open security risks.
== Credit Card Owner Name ==
This is the shortest number of letters you will allow in a credit card owner's name.
== Credit Card Number ==
This is the shortest credit card number that you will allow.
== Review Text ==
This is the shortest number of characters that you will allow when a customer makes a review.
== Best Sellers ==
This is the shortest list of best sellers that you will display on your site.
== Also Purchased ==
This is the shortest list of products that will be displayed in the ''customers who bought this also purchased'' part of the page when a customer is looking at the front page.
== X-Sell ==
This is the minimum number of products to be displayed in the x-sell box.
[[Category:CRE Loaded Features]]

revision.comment: Revert to revision 490237 dated 2006-06-17 19:36:05 by Jguk using [[:en:Wikipedia:Tools/Navigation_popups|popups]]
revision.text:
== Address Book Entries ==
This is the maximum number of addresses that customers can keep in their accounts.
== Search Results ==
This is the maximum number of search results to return - as many people rarely look beyond the first page of the search this option may save some of your server's power.
== Page Links ==
This is the number of page links to display in xxx.
== Special Products ==
The maximum number of products to display that are on special.
== New Products Module ==
This is the maximum number of new products to display.
== Products Expected ==
This is the maximum number of products expected to display in the products expected box.
== Manufacturers List ==
If the number of manufacturers exceeds this number a drop down menu will be used instead of a list box.
== Manufacturers Select Size ==
Set this option to 1 if you want a drop down.
Set this option to more than 1 if you want to have a list box.
== Length of Manufacturers Name ==
Enter the maximum length of a manufacturer's name.
== New Reviews ==
Limit the length of your customers' new reviews here in characters.
== Selection of Random Reviews ==
You can alter the number of entries displayed when customers are presented with a random selection of reviews.
== Selection of Random New Products ==
You can alter the number of entries displayed when customers are presented with a random selection of new products.
== Selection of Products on Special ==
You can alter the number of entries displayed when customers are presented with a random selection of products on special.
== Categories To List Per Row ==
You can choose number of categories per row customer is presented with a list of categories.
== New Products Listing ==
The number of new products to list in the new products listing.
== Best Sellers ==
Limit the number of products listed when the customer is presented with a list of best sellers.
== Also Purchased ==
Limit the number of products in the list when the site recommends to an item's purchaser products that customers also purchased.
== Customer Order History Box ==
You can control the number of orders in the order hsitory box that is displayed.
== Order History ==
Put the maximum number of orders that is displayed in order history.
== Product Featured Maximum Display ==
The maximum number of featured products in the Product Featured box.
== Product Featured Display Results ==
The maximum number results to display when the customer clicks on the Product Featured link.
[[Category:CRE Loaded Features]]

revision.comment: Removed weird philosophical definition of "work" (formerly: "Work is something good that we, as humans value. ")
revision.text:
{{Circuit Theory/Page}} == Electric Charge (Coulombs) == {{SideBox|'''Note:'''
An electron has a charge of
'''-1.602×10E-19''' C.}} [[:w:Electric_charge|'''Electric charge''']] is a [[:w:physical property|physical property]] of [[:w:matter|matter]] that causes it to experience a [[:w:force|force]] when near other electrically charged matter. Electric Charge (symbol q) is measured in SI units called '''"Coulombs"''', which are abbreviated with the letter capital C. We know that q=n*e, where n = number of electrons and e= 1.6*10-19. Hence n=1/e coulombs. A Coulomb is the total charge of 6.24150962915265×1018 electrons, thus a single electron has a charge of −1.602 × 10−19. It is important to understand that this concept of "charge" is associated with static electricity. Charge, as a concept, has a physical boundary that is related to counting a group of electrons. "Flowing" electricity is an [[:w:Electric_charge#Static_electricity_and_electric_current|'''entirely different situation''']]. "Charge" and electrons separate. Charge moves at the speed of light while electrons move at the speed of [[:w:Drift_velocity|'''1 meter/hour''']]. Thus in most circuit analysis, "charge" is an abstract concept unrelated to energy or an electron and more related to the flow of [[:w:Physical_information|'''information''']]. Electric charge is the subject of many fundamental laws, such as [[:w:Coulomb%27s_law|'''Coulomb's Law''']] and [[:w:Gauss%27s_law|'''Gauss' Law''']] (static electricity) but is not used much in circuit theory. == Voltage (Volts) == '''Voltage''' is a measure of the work required to move a charge from one point to another in a electric field. Thus the unit "volt" is defined as a Joules (J) per Coulomb (C). :V = \frac{W}{q} W represents work, q represents an amount of charge. Charge is a static electricity concept. The definition of a volt is shared between static and "flowing" electronics. Voltage is sometimes called "electric potential", because voltage represents the a difference in Electro Motive Force (EMF) that can produce current in a circuit. More voltage means more potential for current. Voltage also can be called "Electric Pressure", although this is far less common. Voltage is not measured in absolutes but in ''relative'' terms. The English language tradition obscures this. For example we say "What is the distance to New York?" Clearly implied is the relative distance from where we are standing to New York. But if we say "What is the voltage at ______?" What is the starting point? Voltage is defined between two points. Voltage is relative to where 0 is defined. We say "The voltage from point A to B is 5 volts." It is important to understand EMF and voltage are two different things. When the question is asked "What is the voltage at ______?", look for the ground symbol on a circuit diagram. Measure voltage from ground to _____. If the question is asked "What is the voltage from A to B?" then put the red probe on A and the black probe on B (not ground). The absolute is referred to as "EMF" or Electro Motive Force. The difference between the two EMF's is a voltage. == Current (Amperes)== '''Current''' is a measurement of the flow of electricity. Current is measured in units called '''Amperes''' (or "Amps"). An ampere is "charge volume velocity" in the same way water current could be measured in "cubic feet of water per second." But current is a [[:w:SI_base_unit|'''base SI unit''']], a fundamental dimension of reality like space, time and mass. A coulomb or charge is not. A coulomb is actually defined in terms of the ampere. "Charge or Coulomb" is a [[:w:SI_derived_units#Derived_units_with_special_names|'''derived SI Unit''']]. The coulomb is a fictitious entity left over from the [[:w:History_of_electromagnetic_theory#Late_18th_century|'''one fluid /two fluid''']] philosophies of the 18th century. This course is about flowing electrical energy that is found in all modern electronics. Charge volume velocity (defined by current) is a useful concept, but understand it has no basis in reality. Do not think of current as a bundle electrons carrying energy through a wire. [[Special_Relativity|Special relativity]] and [[Quantum_Mechanics|quantum mechanics]] concepts are necessary to understand how electrons move at [[:w:Drift_velocity|'''1 meter/hour''']] through copper, yet electromagnetic energy moves at near the speed of light. {{SideBox|[[:w:Electric_charge#Properties|'''Charge''']] is similar to the [[:w:Rest_mass|'''rest mass''']] concept of relativity and generates the [[:w:Charge_(physics)|'''U(1) symmetry''']] of electromagnetism}} Amperes are abbreviated with an "A" (upper-case A), and the variable most often associated with current is the letter "i" (lower-case I). In terms of coulombs, an ampere is: :i = \frac{dq}{dt} {{SideBox|For the rest of this book, the lower-case J ( j ) will be used to denote an imaginary number, and the lower-case I ( i ) will be used to denote current.}} Because of the widespread use of complex numbers in Electrical Engineering, it is common for electrical engineering texts to use the letter "j" (lower-case J) as the imaginary number, instead of the "i" (lower-case I) commonly used in math texts. This wikibook will adopt the "j" as the imaginary number, to avoid confusion. == Energy and Power == Electrical theory is about energy storage and the flow of energy in circuits. Energy is chopped up arbitrarily into something that doesn't exist but can be counted called a coulomb. Energy per coulomb is voltage. The velocity of a coulomb is current. Multiplied together, the units are energy velocity or power ... and the unreal "coulomb" disappears. ===Energy=== Energy is measured most commonly in Joules, which are abbreviated with a "J" (upper-case J). The variable most commonly used with energy is "w" (lower-case W). The energy symbol is w which stands for work. From a thermodynamics point of view, all energy consumed by a circuit is work ... all the heat is turned into work. Practically speaking, this can not be true. If it were true, computers would never consume any energy and never heat up. The reason that all the energy going into a circuit and leaving a circuit is considered "work" is because from a thermodynamic point of view, electrical energy is ideal. All of it can be used. Ideally all of it can be turned into work. Most introduction to thermodynamics courses assume that electrical energy is completely organized (and has entropy of 0). ===Power=== A corollary to the concept of energy being work, is that all the energy/power of a circuit (ideally) can be accounted for. The sum of all the power entering and leaving a circuit should add up to zero. No energy should be accumulated (theoretically). Of course capacitors will charge up and may hold onto their energy when the circuit is turned off. Inductors will create a magnetic field containing energy that will instantly disappear back into the source through the switch that turns the circuit off. This course uses what is called the "[[:w:Electric_power#Passive_sign_convention|passive]]" sign convention for power. Energy put into a circuit by a power supply is negative, energy leaving a circuit is positive. Power (the flow of energy) computations are an important part of this course. The symbol for power is w (for work) and the units are Watts or W.

page.title: Engineering Acoustics/Boundary Conditions and Forced Vibrations

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], typos fixed: displacment → displacement, propogating → propagating (2), typicaly → typically using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Engineering Acoustics}}
== Boundary Conditions ==
The functions representing the solutions to the wave equation previously discussed,
i.e. <math>y(x,t)= f(\xi)+g(\eta)\,</math> with <math>\xi=ct-x\,</math> and <math>\eta=ct+x\,</math>
are dependent upon the boundary and initial conditions. If it is assumed that the wave is propagating through a string, the initial conditions are related to the specific disturbance in the string at t=0. These specific disturbances are determined by location and type of contact and can be anything from simple oscillations to violent impulses. The effects of boundary conditions are less subtle.
The most simple boundary conditions are the Fixed Support and Free End. In practice, the Free End boundary condition is rarely encountered since it is assumed there are no transverse forces holding the string (e.g. the string is simply floating).
=== For a Fixed Support:===
The overall displacement of the waves travelling in the string, at the support, must be zero. Denoting x=0 at the support, This requires:
<math>y(0,t)= f(ct-0)+g(ct+0) = 0\,</math>
Therefore, the total transverse displacement at x=0 is zero.
The sequence of wave reflection for incident, reflected and combined waves are illustrated below. Please note that the wave is traveling to the left (negative '''x''' direction) at the beginning. The reflected wave is ,of course, traveling to the right (positive '''x''' direction).
'''t=0''' [[Image:Fixed_t0.gif]]
'''t=t1''' [[Image:Fixed_t1.gif]]
'''t=t2''' [[Image:Fixed_t2.gif]]
'''t=t3''' [[Image:Fixed_t3.gif]]
=== For a Free Support:===
Unlike the Fixed Support boundary condition, the transverse displacement at the support does not need to be zero, but must require the sum of transverse forces to cancel. If it is assumed that the angle of displacement is small,
<math>\sin(\theta)\approx\theta=\left( \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} \right)\,</math>
and so,
<math>\sum F_{y} = T\sin(\theta)\approx T\left( \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} \right)=0\,</math>
But of course, the tension in the string, or T, will not be zero and this requires the slope at x=0 to be zero:
i.e. <math> \left( \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} \right)=0\,</math>
Again for free boundary, the sequence of wave reflection for incident, reflected and combined waves are illustrated below:
'''t=0''' [[Image:Free_t0.gif]]
'''t=t1''' [[Image:Free_t1.gif]]
'''t=t2''' [[Image:Free_t2.gif]]
'''t=t3''' [[Image:Free_t3.gif]]
=== Other Boundary Conditions:===
There are many other types of boundary conditions that do not fall into our simplified categories. As one would expect though, it isn't difficult to relate the characteristics of numerous "complex" systems to the basic boundary conditions. Typical or realistic boundary conditions include mass-loaded, resistance-loaded, damping-loaded, and impedance-loaded strings. For further information, see Kinsler, Fundamentals of Acoustics, pp 54-58.
Here is a website with nice movies of wave reflection at different BC's: [http://www.ap.stmarys.ca/demos/content/osc_and_waves/wave_reflection/wave_reflection.html Wave Reflection]
== Wave Properties ==
To begin with, a few definitions of useful variables will be discussed. These include; the wave number, phase speed, and wavelength characteristics of wave travelling through a string.
The speed that a wave propagates through a string is given in terms of the phase speed, typically in m/s, given by:
<math>c = \sqrt{T/\rho_{L}}\,</math> where <math>\rho_{L}\,</math> is the density per unit length of the string.
The wave number is used to reduce the transverse displacement equation to a simpler form and for simple harmonic motion, is multiplied by the lateral position. It is given by:
<math>k=\left( \frac{\omega}{c} \right)\,</math> where <math>\omega=2\pi f\,</math>
Lastly, the wavelength is defined as:
<math>\lambda=\left( \frac{2\pi}{k} \right)=\left( \frac{c}{f} \right)\,</math>
and is defined as the distance between two points, usually peaks, of a periodic waveform.
These "wave properties" are of practical importance when calculating the solution of the wave equation for a number of different cases. As will be seen later, the wave number is used extensively to describe wave phenomenon graphically and quantitatively.
For further information: [http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/physics/Wavenumber.html Wave Properties]
== Forced Vibrations == 1.forced vibrations of infinite string suppose there is a string very long , at x=0 there is a force exerted on it.
F(t)=Fcos(wt)=Real{Fexp(jwt)}
use the boundary condition at x=0,
neglect the reflected wave
it is easy to get the wave form
where w is the angular velocity, k is the wave number.
according to the impedance definition
it represents the characteristic impedance of the string. obviously, it is purely resistive, which is like the resistance in the mechanical system.
---- The dissipated power
Note: along the string, all the variables propagate at same speed.
[http://www.mcasco.com/p1apsat.html link title] a useful link to show the time-space property of the wave.
---- Some interesting animations of the wave at different boundary conditions.
1.hard boundary (which is like a fixed end)
2.soft boundary (which is like a free end)
3.from low density to high density string
4.from high density to low density string
[http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Engineering_Acoustics Back to Main page]

page.title: Engineering Acoustics/Boundary Conditions and Wave Properties

revision.text:
{{Engineering Acoustics}}
== Boundary Conditions ==
The functions representing the solutions to the wave equation previously discussed,
i.e. <math>y(x,t)= f(\xi)+g(\eta)\,</math> with <math>\xi=ct-x\,</math> and <math>\eta=ct+x\,</math>
are dependent upon the boundary and initial conditions. If it is assumed that the wave is propagating through a string, the initial conditions are related to the specific disturbance in the string at t=0. These specific disturbances are determined by location and type of contact and can be anything from simple oscillations to violent impulses. The effects of boundary conditions are less subtle.
The most simple boundary conditions are the Fixed Support and Free End. In practice, the Free End boundary condition is rarely encountered since it is assumed there are no transverse forces holding the string (e.g. the string is simply floating).
- For a Fixed Support:
The overall displacement of the waves travelling in the string, at the support, must be zero. Denoting x=0 at the support, This requires:
<math>y(0,t)= f(ct-0)+g(ct+0) = 0\,</math>
Therefore, the total transverse displacement at x=0 is zero.
- For a Free Support:
Unlike the Fixed Support boundary condition, the transverse displacement at the support does not need to be zero, but must require the sum of transverse forces to cancel. If it is assumed that the angle of displacement is small,
<math>\sin(\theta)\approx\theta=\left( \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} \right)\,</math>
and so,
<math>\sum F_{y} = T\sin(\theta)\approx T\left( \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} \right)=0\,</math>
But of course, the tension in the string, or T, will not be zero and this requires the slope at x=0 to be zero:
i.e. <math> \left( \frac{\partial y}{\partial x} \right)=0\,</math>
- Other Boundary Conditions:
There are many other types of boundary conditions that do not fall into our simplified categories. As one would expect though, it isn't difficult to relate the characteristics of numerous "complex" systems to the basic boundary conditions. Typical or realistic boundary conditions include mass-loaded, resistance-loaded, damping-loaded, and impedance-loaded strings. For further information, see Kinsler, Fundamentals of Acoustics, pp 54-58.
== Wave Properties ==
To begin with, a few definitions of useful variables will be discussed. These include; the wave number, phase speed, and wavelength characteristics of wave travelling through a string.
The speed that a wave propagates through a string is given in terms of the phase speed, typically in m/s, given by:
<math>c = \sqrt{T/\rho_{L}}\,</math> where <math>\rho_{L}\,</math> is the density per unit length of the string.
The wave number is used to reduce the transverse displacement equation to a simpler form and for simple harmonic motion, is multiplied by the lateral position. It is given by:
<math>k=\left( \frac{\omega}{c} \right)\,</math> where <math>\omega=2\pi f\,</math>
Lastly, the wavelength is defined as:
<math>\lambda=\left( \frac{2\pi}{k} \right)=\left( \frac{c}{f} \right)\,</math>
and is defined as the distance between two points, usually peaks, of a periodic waveform.
These "wave properties" are of practical importance when calculating the solution of the wave equation for a number of different cases. As will be seen later, the wave number is used extensively to describe wave phenomenon graphically and quantitatively.
For further information: [http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/physics/Wavenumber.html Wave Properties]
[http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Engineering_Acoustics Back to Main page]
