---- *Danish wikibooks user page [[:da:Bruger:KristianMolhave|KristianMolhave]]. *English wikipedia user page [[w:en:user:KristianMolhave|KristianMolhave]]. *[[commons:User:KristianMolhave|Commons user page KristianMolhave]] -where I upload illustrations. *[[User:KristianMolhave/notes| My notes]] ----
I'm working on several wikibooks:
*Opensource handbooks on [[Nanotechnology]] and [[Microtechnology]] *A book about inspiring scientific experiments - Science shows - available in a Danish version ''[[:da:scienceshow| Wiki bogen om science shows]]'' and English version ''[[Scienceshow| The Wiki Book on Science Shows]]''. *[[Teachers'_Toolbox| The Teachers' Toolbox]] an inspirational introduction and overview of teaching and supervision methods.
---- Tools *[http://www.alexa.com/data/details/traffic_details?url=en.wikibooks.org website statistics, visitors to wikibooks]
#REDIRECT [[Scienceshow/Guides]]

The template is shown without wiki formatting - so cut from below the line and paste it into your new page and you're ready to create a new guide! You can see how it looks [[../Template |here.]]
Remember the guide you're writing must have a title as "Scienceshow/Guides/title" by always first starting the new page as a link in the page [[Scienceshow/Guides]].
[[commons:scienceshow| Wikimedia Commons ScienceShow]] is where we upload the media files for this book to have an easy overview of available images etc.
<center> Cut below </center>
----
__NOTOC__
<nowiki>==Purpose and Overview==</nowiki>
Make a brief statement about the purpose of this specific guide you're making in this section. Briefly describe what the experiment is about. Which scientific principles does it demonstrate?
Replace the guiding test in the template as your write, but keep the egneral structure and leave the text in empty sections so other contributors will know what it is intended for.
Remember that no copyrighted material can be added to this book without the authors explicit accept and please ackowledge sources of information and ideas with links to websites and references.
Media files should be uploaded on <nowiki>[[commons:scienceshow| Wikimedia Commons ScienceShow]]</nowiki>.
<nowiki>*Status for this guide: Finished, Not yet finished, Check recipes...(leave the appropriate)</nowiki>
<nowiki>*Subjects relating to this guide: add appropriate...[[../Nanotechnology/]], [[../Physics/]]</nowiki>
<nowiki>__TOC__</nowiki>
<nowiki>==Safety==</nowiki>
<nowiki>===Safety Class===</nowiki>
Choose a fitting safety class for this description
<nowiki>*'''Too dangerous!''' (We do not make this experiment because …)</nowiki>
<nowiki>*Very dangerous (Should only be attempted after careful training)</nowiki>
<nowiki>*Dangerous - Please be aware of this or the other thing... (Untrained people can do this experiment under supervision and guidance)</nowiki>
<nowiki>*Harmless (The most dangerous thing is this insignificant little petitesse)</nowiki>
<nowiki>===Required Safety Equipment===</nowiki>
<nowiki>*The show performer: Glasses / Lab coat / Nothing / Fire extinguisher / Wet towel and a bucket of water / Eye flushing bottle </nowiki>
<nowiki>*Audience/participants: Safety screens / Hearing protection (a finger in the ear is often a help).</nowiki>
<nowiki>==Materials==</nowiki>
You'll need the following - make a list
<nowiki>* item 1: formula, CAS number, supplier [http://www.someshop.com], Safety issues (describe the most important ones), Storage, link to safety datasheet</nowiki>
<nowiki>==Procedure==</nowiki>
<nowiki>*Preparation time</nowiki>
<nowiki>*Performance time</nowiki>
<nowiki>*Clean-up time.</nowiki>
<nowiki>===Step by step===</nowiki>
<nowiki>#Start by…</nowiki>
<nowiki>#…</nowiki>
<nowiki>#End with explaining how to properly get rid of waste products</nowiki>
<nowiki>===Alternative methods===</nowiki>
Other ways to do the experiment
<nowiki>===Dangers===</nowiki>
Now the reader knows the experiment, give a closer description of possible dangers.
<nowiki>*Important, be aware of…</nowiki>
<nowiki>*Consider the…</nowiki>
<nowiki>===Other Factors===</nowiki>
What other things can sometimes affect the result of the experiment. Maybe the humidity or cleanliness of the glass ware is an issue.
<nowiki>===Show notes===</nowiki>
What to consider when preparing. How to make it more spectacular. What can be difficult to achieve 'on stage' that normally is easy when practising.
What other experiments are good to that have in relation to this one?
What should you beware of that can make the experiment boring?
<nowiki>==Explanation==</nowiki>
<nowiki>===What's taking place===</nowiki>
Here you can give a more quantitative and mathematical description of what happens. What fundamental laws are involved or demonstrated by this experiment etc. Remember to explain jargon/expressions from the laboratory.
<nowiki>===In the real world===</nowiki>
Do you meet things like this in daily life - give examples!
<nowiki>===Unanswered Questions===</nowiki>
Things we do not yet know and should find an answer to - maybe how it actually works etc.
<nowiki>==More Information==</nowiki>
<nowiki>*[http://end.net Websites with more info] the end.</nowiki>
<nowiki>===Acknowledgements===</nowiki>
<nowiki>===References===</nowiki>
See <nowiki>[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes Wikipedia:Footnotes]</nowiki> for an explanation of how to generate footnotes using the <nowiki><nowiki><ref></nowiki></nowiki> and <nowiki><nowiki></ref></nowiki></nowiki> tags <nowiki><ref> example reference </ref></nowiki>.
<nowiki><references /></nowiki>
<nowiki>==Remember==</nowiki>
This is just a guide and it can contain both errors and omissions. Always make experiments in small versions before proceeding to larger quantities where things could become dangerous. Ask around if you have any doubts before starting and do not start on a procedure you do not feel you understand and is qualified to perform.
<nowiki> {{BookCat}} </nowiki>
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: /* Download Packages to Enable malayalam support in GNU/Linux */ grammar
revision.text:
This guide is for configuring your computer to enable reading and writing [[w:Malayalam language|Malayalam]] in Windows, and GNU/Linux and BSD operating systems.
== Microsoft Windows == === Configuring for reading === #Delete any old version of [http://varamozhi.sourceforge.net/fonts/AnjaliOldLipi.ttf AnjaliOldLipi] Font from Fonts directory which is often C:\WINDOWS\Fonts or C:\WINNT\Fonts. #Download and copy [http://varamozhi.sourceforge.net/fonts/AnjaliOldLipi.ttf AnjaliOldLipi.ttf] to Windows\Fonts folder. #Click Start, Control Panel, Internet Options, Fonts. Select Language Script Malayalam. Then select Web page font as [http://varamozhi.sourceforge.net/fonts/AnjaliOldLipi.ttf AnjaliOldLipi]. Press OK and OK.
=== Configuring for Writing ===
'''Varamozhi''' [http://varamozhi.sourceforge.net Varamozhi] Editor is a transliteration based Malayalam text Editor that runs on both Windows and Unix. That is, you can type in Manglish and you will see in real Malayalam. [[Image:Malayalam-Mozhi-Lipi.png|frame|left|Basic Mozhi Transliteration Scheme]] Also, you can copy-paste any Malayalam article from some web site and that will be converted back to Manglish for correction, further editing or conversion to Unicode or another font.
=== Language packs === You can install the Malayalam language pack for your operating system to see the Microsoft Windows GUI in Malayalam.
== GNU/Linux and *BSD*s == * All latest GNU/Linux distributions support Malayalam well. You may need to follow specific installation guides from [http://smc.org.in Swathanthra malayalam Computing] to configure it well * You can see a how to to enable malayalam in your computer @ the [http://malayalam.web4all.in Malayalam Computing Portal]
Here are the steps to enable support. * pango enabled firefox does provide good indic fonts support.In [http://debian.org/ Debian GNU/Linux] Iceweasel provides the best indic rendition.You can enable Gnome browser epiphany for pango support via gconf2 tool as epiphany also is based on gecko.
* If your distribution does not come with any indic font(here,Malayalam), you will need to install one.
=== Installing Font in Gnome,Kde and X in general ===
* Download [http://download.savannah.gnu.org/releases/smc/fonts/malayalam-fonts-04/ Malayalam Unicode fonts]] and copy it to fonts:/// Directory
* All major distributions comes with malayalam fonts. Use apt-get install ttf-malayalam-fonts in Debian based distributions(Debian Ubuntu etc ) and yum install smc-fonts in fedora
===In Gnome=== '''[http://www.gnome.org GNOME]''' is a versatile Desktop Environment with native pango support which means better rendering in-built. *In Gnome,drag n drop your font to nautilus window.before,nautilus should be in Fonts:/// directory(press CTRL+L,enter fonts:/// ). Now press CTRL+ALT+BKSPACE to restart X and gdm.next time the font is available for local user and installed in ~/.fonts/ directory.
=== Installing TrueType fonts in X in general and also for Gnome ===
*there are other ways to make font available to all users of the system in Gnome or X itself.I am taking Debian/Ubuntu as example,but works for any distro too.for redhat/fedora and Suse or most distros this works.rpm based distros got a tool called [http://www.dinakaran.com/fonts/linux/ chkfontpath] which is very useful. Now,you need to use CLI or terminal for implementing this.firstly: "apt-get install ttmkfdir" using apt package management tool or use Synaptic Manager. make a directory called malayalam and copy the Anjali font to there. :~# mkdir /usr/share/fonts/truetype/malayalam/ move the font here. then go to /usr/share/fonts/truetype/malayalam/ -where font is installed. You need to be root user for installing fonts globally.for that in a terminal, su [press enter] <give your root password> or sudo [press enter] <give your local password> sudo is used in Ubuntu Linux by default.
then as root("~#" stands for root prompt,dont copy that), ~#ttmkfdir> fonts.scale ~#mkfontscale ~#ttmkfdir >fonts.dir ~#mkfontdir ~#xset fp+ /usr/share/fonts/truetype/malayalam/ ~#xset fp rehash now do a, ~#fc-cache -fv restart Display(X) or reboot.As /usr/share/fonts/truetype/ directory is already mapped in Xorg for fonts.(see /etc/X11/fs/config). Now the font can be used by every users.
=== Kde Desktop Environment === Kde is the most used Desktop Environment in GNU/Linux and *NIX's too: * In KDE Control Center (kcontrol), select System Administration -> Font Installer, and add the downloaded font * You may need to logout and login back
*For Transliteration or manglish(type malayalam in English) in GNU/Linux and *BSDs,we can use a various inputs systems [http://smc.org.in Swanalekha] (Phonetic Keyboard using SCIM) or [http://smc.org.in mozhi]. otherwise you can compile from source the [http://varamozhi.wikia.com/wiki/Varamozhi Varamozhi] Transliteration tool for Malayalam.
=== Download Packages to Enable malayalam support in GNU/Linux === You can download the software required to enable Malayalam support in the latest version of Ubuntu(7.10) and Debian GNU/Linux (etch) from http://malayalam.kerala.gov.in
Use the repositories of Swathanthra Malayalam Computing to keep updated. Swathanthra Malayalam Computing manages repositories for Fedora 6, 7, 8, 9 , CentOS5 and Debain etch, lenny and sid
{{BookCat}}
